BC.passage: BC ------- BC is the abbreviation for Before Christ, denoting a period of time in the Gregorian calendar preceding the year of the traditionally recognized birth of Jesus Christ. The BC era began with the year 1 BC, and ended with the year AD 1, when the era of the Anno Domini (AD) began. The concept of BC and AD was introduced by the Christian theologian Dionysius Exiguus in the 6th century, who based his calculations on the work of the earlier Jewish historian Josephus. The system was widely adopted in Europe and is now used throughout the world for dating events and historical periods. The BC era is characterized by a number of significant historical events and developments, including the rise and fall of ancient civilizations such as the Greeks, Romans, and Egyptians, as well as the emergence of new cultures and societies in Asia and the Americas. Many of the major religious and philosophical traditions that continue to shape the world today also emerged during this period. Despite its religious connotations, the BC era is widely used in secular contexts, particularly in academic and historical research, where it provides a useful framework for dating and comparing events and trends across different cultures and time periods.

The word "tempura" comes from the Portuguese word "tempero," which means "to temper" or "to mix." Tempura is often served with a dipping sauce made from soy sauce, mirin, and dashi. However, it was not until the Edo period (1603–1868) that tempura became a popular dish among the Japanese people. Tempura is typically made by dipping the seafood, vegetables, and mushrooms in a mixture of flour, eggs, and water, before coating them in a batter made from tempura flour and deep-frying them until crispy. Tempura is often served with a variety of side dishes, including pickled vegetables, grated daikon radish, and tempura sauce. It is also commonly served as a topping on ramen, udon, and soba noodles.
